Bargain nappy rash cream hits the spots
Wacky gadgets claim to help women shun cosmetic surgery
Bow to force of the brow

articles.articlebody:
THIS is the season to embrace dewy skin. Forget heavy tans, thick layers of foundation and cakey bronzer  radiance is now the key word in the beauty world.

Catwalk models have all been given little else but radiant, glowing skin, while celebrities such as Natalie Portman are setting the precedent for softer, fresher looks.

If YOU fancy brightening your complexion, a few simple tricks can lift your skin.

LAUREN NAYLOR shares her skin secrets so you can get up and glow.

Skin perfection



LET'S face it, we'd all love to feel confident make-up free and be blessed with a radiant, glowy complexion.

But daily exposure to harsh elements can make it difficult to pull off. Look out for nourishing and calming skincare ingredients to give your skin radiance and combat dryness and redness.

Head therapist Sherelle at celebrity skin care spa Linda Meredith, whose clients include Kate Beckinsale and Gwyneth Paltrow, says: "Start by using a cleanser packed full of naturally occurring vitamins, omega oils and amino acids.

"We are exposed to various chemicals throughout our day so look for paraben-free formulas.

"Take a generous amount of cleansing product mixed with warm water and with a feather-soft touch gently massage the product in with your fingertips.

"By massaging softly you are pushing the product into your skin rather than moving facial muscles about aggressively.

And the warm water heats the skin for the products to penetrate deeper. When you rinse, use a soft sponge, gentle cotton wool pads or your hands  flannels are too abrasive.

"An old-school, tried-and-tested method that we use is to give your skin a deep steam once a week over the basin. This will help open up and deep-clean any clogged pores.

"There is nothing wrong with squeezing out blackheads  just make sure you take a thick piece of tissue and use the sides of your fingertips to push them out.

"Only do this for three to five minutes max. If they won't come, they're not ready, and if you use your fingernails you will break and damage your skin."

We love REN Hydra-Calm Cleansing Milk with peroxidase enzymes from fennel seed extract to protect distressed skin and Omega 3 and 7 essential fatty acids to reduce inflammation, £18.

Linda Meredith Paraben-free Cream Cleanser with avocado and citrus fruit oils, £39 (stockists, 020 7225 2755). Team with a brightening moisturiser such as Simple Radiance Brightening Moisturiser, £6.99 (Boots).

Pep up



IF your complexion is looking lacklustre, it's likely you need to exfoliate sluggish skin cells. Look for natural ingredients that gently slough off dead skin.

Walnut shell, papaya and pineapple are all fantastic natural exfoliators. Try Origins Never A Dull Moment skin-brightening polisher with fruit extracts to help reveal a healthy glow, £24 (Origins).

Put your feet up and slather on Elemis Papaya Enzyme Peel, £28.60 (Elemis counters). We love the intoxicating Victoria sponge-like scent.

Make me up



SKIN highlighters add radiance in an instant. You can layer under make-up or wear stand-alone.

If you are going out and want to appear more made up, try adding highlighter along the cheekbones, down the bridge of the nose and on the forehead  this gives a shimmering dewiness.

You can also place highlighter on the brow bone and under the arch of the brow to make your eyes appear brighter.

L'Oreal Lumi Magique Concealer, £8.49, (Boots) will help to brighten the eyes if you dab a small amount in the darkest areas, ie, underneath, and Bobbi Brown Creamy Concealer in Chestnut, £17, is great for darker skins. Gorgeously rich and luxurious, MAC's Strobe Cream is used by many of the world's high-profile make-up artists.

Wear it under or over make-up for a dewy, almost wet-look effect and team with MAC's Lustre Drops in Sun Rush, £17.50, for a pop of warmth.

Last but not least, finish your face with a burst of brightening blusher on the apples of your cheeks such as Gosh Natural Blush in Electric Pink, Max Factor Miracle Touch Creamy Blush in Soft Pink, £6.99, or Maybelline NY Dream Soft Blush in Peach 02, £4.49 (all Superdrug).
articles.teaser: FORGET heavy tans and thick layers of foundation  radiance is the key word on the catwalk
articles.headline: Go with the glow
articles.subdeck: Shine on ... glossy skin is season's must-have

image.caption: 'Men should wear the trousers' ... Martin Daubney

article.caption: Girl power-steering
Are women better at parking than men?

articles.articlebody:
SO a new survey tells us the depressing news that two thirds of British men let their women dress them for work.

Or, to put it another way: Only a third of men actually wear the trousers any more.

I wonder if these women spit on a hanky and scrub away a stray fleck of Weetabix from their fellas' mouths.

Because these treacherous blokes are still allowing themselves to be mothered to death  and letting down the rest of mankind.

It's blatantly not in a woman's best interests to make a man look as sharp or hot as he can. No sane man would dress his missus in heels, stockings and a minidress before packing her out the door unattended, would he?

So these men will be draped in nice, safe  even slightly offensive  clobber.

The most confident and attractive men in history dress for women, and never get dressed by them. Take this to its sexless extreme and you get those weird couples that dress identically.

From behind, it's impossible to see who's wearing the trousers.

Even celebrities who dress the same look daft. Take Posh when she cajoled Becks into sporting a matching head-to-toe leather ensemble.

I lost all respect for an old friend of mine when he turned up to the office in Crocs. He said: "The missus got them two for one in Lidl." He was chastised by all, especially the ladies present. A part of Chris died that day and we never looked at him the same again.

By allowing his missus to dress him up, he quite rightly earned the ultimate dressing down.
articles.byline: By MARTIN DAUBNEY, Former Editor of lads’ mag Loaded
articles.teaser: AS two thirds of men admit to being dressed by their partner, former Loaded Ed on why they're letting mankind down
articles.headline: Dress for women (not by them)
articles.subdeck: 'Men should wear the trousers' ... Martin Daubney

image.caption: Stay fit and quit ... tips to giving up cigarettes while keeping trim

article.caption: Ten tips to help you quit smoking
I lost my unborn baby due to smoking... Stacey, please don't do the same

articles.articlebody:
SHOCKING pictures of Stacey Solomon smoking while seven months pregnant horrified the nation.

The 22-year-old X Factor star says she has tried to kick the habit but the fags keep getting the better of her.

Weight gain is fairly common among ex-smokers and is a major reason why some women don't give up.

Here, nutritionist AMANDA URSELL and fitness expert NICKI WATERMAN tell you how to avoid piling on the pounds after you've stubbed out that final ciggie.



Diet tips



AMANDA SAYS: "Giving up smoking can lead to the pounds, if not stones, piling on.

"This is partly because nicotine seems to bump up the metabolism by about seven per cent. It appears to have a pretty instant effect that lasts for about 30 minutes per cigarette.

"The stronger the nicotine content, the greater this metabolism-boosting effect.

"Smoking also seems to help to suppress the appetite. It does this in part by helping to block the action of chemicals in the brain that stimulate hunger.

"But it is important to put things into perspective and to appreciate that, although some people do put on a lot of weight after quitting cigarettes, the average gain is between three and ten pounds.

"The good news is that some experts report that using nicotine patches helps to lower appetite, and that those who use them while trying to quit gain less weight than those who do not. Having regular 'doses' of carbohydrate may also help to beat the hunger pangs which may be triggered by quitting.

"And on the day you decide to give up, make sure you have breakfast and keep up this habit.

"Not having anything to eat first thing can be a real problem because, by mid-morning, your body will not only be craving its usual nicotine fix but will also have low blood sugar.

"It is important when giving up smoking to remember that, even though cigarettes appear to help a bit in the battle of the bulge, there are plenty of slim people who do not smoke and plenty of overweight people who do smoke.

"Continuing to smoke because you think giving up will make you fat is no excuse not to try quitting.

"Doing so could well save your life."



5 point weight proof plan



1. Don't give up when you are tired. Being tired always makes you more hungry.

2. Throw out fattening foods that might tempt you. If you can't do this, put them in a cupboard away from day-to-day foods so you are not constantly seeing them.

3. Stock up on healthy snacks such as satsumas, grapes, low-fat yogurts, small 30g servings of nuts like almonds, cashews and peanuts and some miniature dark-chocolate Green & Black's bars that you can nibble on when the nicotine withdrawal triggers hunger pangs.

4. Drink at least six to eight cups or mugs of fluids each day to help keep hydrated. Being dehydrated can make you stressed and grumpy. It is not a good idea to try to quit caffeine-containing drinks at the same time as giving up cigarettes.

5. Eat breakfast, lunch and dinner and have a small snack in between to ensure that levels of sugar in your blood are steady and stable.

Eggs on toast, cereal or fruit salad and yogurt make good breakfasts.

Tuna, chicken or hummus-stuffed pitta or wraps are examples of energy-extending lunches and spaghetti Bolognese, baked potato with baked-bean toppings, stir fries and omelettes make good dinners.



How exercise can help



NICKI SAYS: "A new study has discovered that vigorous exercise can have a positive impact on the success rate of women trying to give up smoking.

"This is exciting news, especially when combined with previous research that shows exercising for one to two hours a week while quitting also significantly reduces the amount of weight gained.

"By incorporating exercise into your quitting programme, the feelgood endorphins your body produces also help you to overcome the mood swings that come with quitting."



Tips to give up smoking



Commit to daily exercise sessions during the first month of quitting. Preferably in the morning to perk your mood up for the day ahead.

Sign up to classes, if you can, to keep you on track and schedule in things like swimming and cycling. If you prefer, a fast 30-minute walk, skipping or working out to a DVD at home all count.

Exercise can help to relieve stress, making it the ideal antidote to tense moments during the day, which can otherwise leave you reaching for the ciggies.

Work out what your cigarette triggers are. If you reach for one when you pick up the phone, walk up and down the stairs instead while chatting. Or if you can, go outside and talk while you walk.

If your trigger is when you relax in front of the telly, stop watching and try skipping indoors or, again, go for a walk to distract you. Work out your own problem moments and plan ahead to avoid them by replacing them with something active.

Define your goals. If you don't have a specific goal, your training will lack direction.

To help support your goals, look for programmes that match your needs. For example, if you're running a race to raise money for charity, most charities provide training programmes.

Or, try one of the many fitness apps  Nike Training Club, for instance, is free to download.

Keep a training diary. Once you've worked out your training programme, it's important to keep a record of your workouts in a diary.

The easiest, quickest way to log details is to develop a code for the type and length of workout you do.

It also means you can add up your total number of exercise minutes each week. Aim to increase what you do until you have reached four to six hours a week.

Stop boredom creeping in. One of the biggest reasons we fall out of love with fitness is getting stuck in a rut.

Why not try inline skating or join a sports team? Aim to do at least two different types of cardiovascular exercise a week, whether it's running, cycling or swimming.

This keeps your body challenged and mind engaged.

Any activity that focuses your mind will ensure you use your body more effectively so you'll get better results.

Ideal activities include martial arts such as t'ai chi, karate, capoeira or yoga and Pilates.

Get a big exercise high. There's nothing like a high-intensity workout to give you an exercise high and get you wanting more.

Research shows intense bouts of exercise release more feelgood hormones and get you fitter quicker. Do at least one good stretch and relaxation session each week as well.
articles.teaser: NUTRITION and fitness experts tell you how to avoid piling on the pounds after you've quit smoking for good
articles.headline: Be a quitter and keep your figure
articles.subdeck: Stay fit and quit ... tips to giving up cigarettes while keeping trim

image.caption: Different perspective ... Renee Zellweger says that she feels lucky to have European parents

article.caption: Jerry Maguire actor's grown up to be a big star

articles.articlebody:
RENEE ZELLWEGER became a star thanks to her role opposite Tom Cruise in 1996 hit movie Jerry Maguire.

She is now established as one of the best-known and most highly paid actresses in Hollywood.

She won an Oscar for her role in the drama Cold Mountain and is famous for two films playing Bridget Jones.

Renee, 42, who had a short-lived marriage to singer Kenny Chesney in 2005, lives alone.

Here, she tells GARTH PEARCE about the influence her Norwegian-born mum Kjellfrid has had on her.

I DIDN'T grow up in a house where Mum focused on appearances. I don't remember her ever saying, "Wouldn't you be pretty if you did this or that?"

She never focused on anything beyond wanting me to be presentable  just well-groomed.

She wanted me to take care of myself and be healthy.

She did ask one or two questions when I became a cheerleader at high school because I would be teasing my hair and wearing lipstick and eyeliner.

I have an affiliation with a lot of countries. My mum was from Norway, my dad from Switzerland and my grandmother was Finnish, I have an Italian uncle, my first love was from South Africa and I was born in Texas.

I am definitely a Texan girl. It is a culture you really love in a Latin sort of way. You taste it and hear it and the climate is hot  Texas hot.

I felt lucky that my parents were European  different  and opened the doors to let me see America is not the centre of the universe.

It meant that, with Bridget Jones, I could go to London and enjoy all things English that make the country so wonderful.

During the making of the first film, I was even whistling songs by the Spice Girls.

But my mum was a realist about bringing up a teenage girl in America and kept a sense of humour.

She taught me that there are consequences for the things you say and do. She wanted me to grow up to be a good person. She and Dad liked simple and quiet. We had a very quiet house.

My mum didn't talk about her childhood growing up in Norway during the Second World War. Her sisters talked but all had difficulty in putting into words what they had seen.

They told about women giving birth in tunnels because there was no safe haven in any other structure.

And about being lost from family members and not being sure if they were alive.

So it was different for me, from my friends, growing up in a house where your mother was grateful just to have peace.

There was one thing which was never acceptable, though.

When I said: "I don't know how to do that", she would say: "Learn."

She encouraged me to get a college education (Renee has an English degree) as something to fall back on if acting didn't work out.

I moved to Los Angeles on December 6, 1993, to be exact.

My attitude was that I was going to see where it took me.

I had been working in Texas from the age of 21, and been in a couple of films. But I had pretty well exhausted my learning opportunities.

So I took a grungy little one-bed apartment and was scared to death of the future. It was a leap of faith, I guess.

I had some friends in LA who I had met on films but inside and emotionally, I felt alone.

To make a living, I worked in a bar called The Three Cubs on a street called Vine, behind the Mobil gas station.

It was an incredible place for a girl like me, who had lived in relatively safe places all her life.

There were crack deals being done on the street corners  so I would come back from the bar late at night then not be able to get out of my car to my apartment until the deals were completed.

I worked at the bar for two years. That was why Mum's guidance was so important and I stayed happy.

When you can take care of yourself and see your friends, that is all that matters.

The main difference that the film Jerry Maguire made in my life was I could pay my rent and didn't have to waitress any more. It gave me freedom.

I knew from the start that if I failed in acting, I always had my degree and could try a million things. I was not a "look at me" kind of girl.

I had gravitated toward acting because I had a vivid imagination and daydreamed a lot.

But I did not daydream about being on a film set, winning an Oscar or having people know my name.

I am grateful for the fact my mum never worried that I would compromise myself.

She was always telling me, 'You don't sit down enough'  but she learned to trust my instincts.
articles.teaser: ACTRESS Renee Zellweger reveals how her Norwegian mother influenced her career
articles.headline: Renee's European parents
articles.subdeck: Different perspective ... Renee Zellweger says that she feels lucky to have European parents

image.caption: Kelly Brook ... is the shape of a butternut squash

article.caption: Kelly Brook does sock and awe for Sports Relief

articles.articlebody:
ONE in five women are the shape of a BUTTERNUT SQUASH, reveals a new poll.

Kelly Brook and Mad Men beauty Christina Hendricks are examples. Their bust and hip sizes are the same but their waist is smaller by about 10in.

Experts also found one in four British women are carrot-shaped, 23 per cent are pears and 18 per cent are apples.

Big-hipped aubergines and busty broccolis scored less than six per cent each.

The survey, for the Vitality Show  from March 22 to 25 at London's Earls Court  studied 3,000 volunteers.

So are you a fruit or a vegetable? Use our guide.

SINGERS Jennifer Hudson and Kerry Katona are typical. Your waist is equal to or larger than your hips and bust. You only have 2-4 inches difference between all three.

ACTRESS Lindsay Lohan and TV presenter Ulrika Jonsson are broccoli-shaped.

Your bust is the widest part and your hips and waist are about the same size.

HOLLYWOOD A-listers Cameron Diaz and Nicole Kidman come under this category.

Your bust and hips are wider than your waist but only by about 6-8 inches.

THINK singer Jennifer Lopez or Sex And The City's Kristin Davis.

Your waist is at least 10in smaller than your hips. But your bust isn't as large as your hips.

CLAIRE RICHARDS from Steps and singer Adele are this shape.

Your bust is the smallest measurement and hips the largest. Your waist size lies between the two.
articles.teaser: ONE in five women are the shape of a BUTTERNUT SQUASH. So are you a fruit or a vegetable? Find out here
articles.headline: Why Kelly's a butternut squash
articles.subdeck: Kelly Brook ... is the shape of a butternut squash

image.caption: I thee fed ... couple

article.caption: Bloater to boater
End of the fat blue line
Man's waist measures more than his height
Slim boy 'fat'
I weighed more than my whole family

articles.articlebody:
A WOMAN who is trying to become the fattest in the world is getting married  to a CHEF.

Susanne Eman says her relationship with Parker Clack, 35, is "perfect".

She said: "We are a match made in heaven. I love eating and Parker loves cooking.

"He can help me reach my goal by feeding me."

Mum-of-two Susanne, 33, weighs about 54stone but hopes to reach more than 115stone to become the biggest person ever.

She said of her fiancé: "His cooking was part of the attraction. How could I resist a man with talents in the kitchen?

"His spaghetti bolognese is my favourite. I could eat it all day."

Parker, who lives with Susanne in Casa Grande, Arizona, calls himself a "Fat Admirer".

He said: "I support her, it makes her happy, and I love big women.

"I do worry about her health but eating puts a smile on her face."
articles.teaser: A WOMAN who is trying to reach 115 stone is getting married  to a FOODIE
articles.headline: 'Fat vow' Sue engaged to chef
articles.subdeck: I thee fed ... couple

image.caption: Slumperland ... girl recovers on a pavement of Britain's booze death capital

article.caption: Why we're all tee totally happy
Sunderland worst for alcohol deaths

articles.articlebody:
A YOUNG reveller lies slumped on the pavement in Sunderland  Britain's booze death capital.

Last week we revealed residents of the north-east city are more likely to drink themselves to death than in any other place in England and Wales.

In 2010 alone 36 people died there from alcohol-related illnesses.

Yet on Friday night The Sun saw 5pm to 5am pub crawls, girls as young as 16 downing cheap booze and a man in his 60s collapsed covered in blood.

One 23-year-old told us he'd rather DIE than stop drinking.

Britney Moore, 16, who was downing alcopops, said: "I'm not surprised by the statistics. We all like a drink here. There's nothing else to do on a night.

"I've got friends who have been going out since they were 14. It's easy to get your hands on drink at a young age."

Rachel Halliday, 27, added: "Last year someone was dying in the street and people walked past thinking he was drunk."
articles.teaser: SUNDERLAND residents ignore research they are more likely to drink selves to death
articles.headline: Sunder the influence...
articles.subdeck: Slumperland ... girl recovers on a pavement of Britain's booze death capital

image.caption: Holly Francis ... slim and healthy after tragic miscarriage prompted dramatic weight loss

article.caption: 'I'm proud to be UK average size 16. And I'll never yo-yo again'
I gave mum my kidney for Mother's Day

articles.articlebody:
SCOOPING up stacks of empty takeaway cartons from the dinner table, Holly Francis knew her junk-food diet was out of control.

A shocking intake of more than 6,000 calories a day meant 23-year-old Holly's weight had climbed up to 22st.

And the obese customer service worker discovered her chip-fuelled teas and kebab suppers were not only hitting her health, she had shelled out £25,000 on takeaway food.

And when Holly suffered a miscarriage at 12 weeks  and discovered obesity could have caused it  she knew she had to switch to a healthy new lifestyle.

Holly, now 27, from Needham Market, Suffolk, dramatically changed her eating habits and shed an amazing 11st in 16 months.

Here she talks to NIKKI WATKINS about why she is much happier now she's sacked her takeaway addiction.

SINGLE Holly's diet was completely out control and her health was failing.

She says: "When I look at how much the food cost me  £25,000  it is amazing and terrible.

"When the tragedy struck and I suffered a miscarriage, I knew it was time to seriously change my lifestyle."

Holly's problems began when she started dating a long-term boyfriend at the age of 15, when she was a size ten.

She says: "I was only young when I met my now ex-boyfriend and we dated for ten years.

"I was eating very little and doing lots of exercise. I was unhealthily skinny.

"After meeting my boyfriend I started gaining weight.

"We went out eating and drinking and this became our social life together.

"That was when I started to gain weight. It was creeping on and, by September 2005 when I was 21, I weighed 18st 7lb.

"I began work on the reception in a Chinese takeaway and started to eat takeaway food at least three times a week.

"But I didn't just have Chinese. There were also McDonald's, pizza and kebabs. I would eat any kind of takeaway.

"This bad habit of eating junk came from laziness and the fact I was working evenings and training to be a nurse.

"My boyfriend couldn't cook and I didn't want to, so it was easier to grab and go.

"We would do no exercise, watch films on TV, have a takeaway and then go to bed.

"One day the realisation of my obesity hit me like a lead weight.

"I couldn't fit the clothes in normal dress shops and I was very uncomfortable."

Wanting to lose weight instantly, Holly tried a crash diet.

She says: "I went on a liquid diet and in six months I had shot down to 11st 4lb.

"But the diet was awful, my hair was falling out and I was bruising from head to toe.

"I realised how unhealthy I was and I started to eat normal food again in March 2006.

"But by September 2009 I had gained a staggering 11st. I had gone back to eating takeaways and secret eating too.

"I would secretly eat anything I could get my hands on  crisps, cakes, biscuits and bars and bars of chocolate.

"My diet was terrible, I was eating easily 6,000 calories a day.

"Breakfast would be five slices of toast with peanut butter and five Weetabix. Lunch would be two cheese toasties and a McDonald's, and dinner would be pizza and chips. I would also snack on a packet of crumpets a day, two pork pies and a packet of six cakes. I became compulsive. I was unhappy with my job in insurance, after I gave up nursing, and food became an obsession.

"I was eating to numb my feelings of unhappiness.

"At my heaviest, in September 2009, I weighed a staggering 22st 9lb, and was wearing a size 28 dress. I went on holiday with my friends and on the airplane I had to ask for an extension on my seatbelt.

"And I was not allowed on a waterpark ride because I didn't fit on it. It was all so mortifying.

"Two months later I separated from my partner of ten years and was devastated.

"A couple of months later my ex and I had a one-night stand and I fell pregnant.

"Though we'd had our problems, we wanted to keep the baby. I was so, so happy."

But sadly, at 12 weeks, Holly miscarried. She says: "I lost the baby three days before my first scan. I was shell-shocked and heart-broken. It hit me like a brick as I realised I may have lost the baby because I was so overweight. The gynaecologist said to me afterwards that excess weight can cause miscarriage.

"I did a lot of research on the internet and came to my own conclusion that I did miscarry because of my weight.

"It was at this point I thought, 'Holly, you have got to sort yourself out.' "

Holly and her boyfriend separated properly and she spent the next 16 months living a healthy lifestyle and again lost weight.

She says: "I started being careful with my food and calorie counting.

"I started drinking two litres of water every day with green tea and redbush tea.

"I also kept a food diary to keep me motivated.

"There were lots of small things that I changed in my life.

"I stopped driving to the shops, started going for long walks in my lunch hour, taking the stairs instead of the lift and jogging.

"I couldn't afford the gym so I took exercise where I could and when it was free.

"After 16 months I was delighted when I stepped on the scales and saw that I had lost 11st and size 12 clothes fitted me comfortably. I had lost an incredible eight dress sizes.

"My friends and family have helped me no end with my new healthy lifestyle.

"My little sister (drama teacher Chelsea Francis, 24) has filled my new wardrobe and has given me bags and bags of clothes. And my other sister (make-up artist Danielle Francis, 28) gave me a makeover."

Holly is adamant her overindulging ways are behind her and she is sticking to her new lifestyle.

She says: "I really hope the amount I spent on takeaways makes people in this obesity crisis think twice about buying junk food.

"People think they can't afford to do a big food shop because it is too expensive, but so are takeaways.

"You could easily spend £20 a time on a takeaway and if you do that a few times a week it comes to the same as your shopping bill.

"Looking back to the slob on the sofa that I was, I feel like I have been given a new lease of life.

"I feel like someone has given me another chance.

"I am devastated I lost my baby and not a day goes by when I don't think about it. But I have things to be grateful for too.

"I have my health back and I am a very happy person and have such a positive outlook on life.

"I still enjoy the odd takeaway but I just choose the healthier options now like Chinese chicken and bean sprouts.

"I am looking for a nice young man now  that is next on my list of things to do."

What she ate then (6000 calories)



BREAKFAST: Five slices of peanut butter on toast and five Weetabix

LUNCH: Two cheese toasties and a McDonald's

DINNER: Pizza and chips

SNACKS: Packet of crumpets, two pork pies and a pack of six cakes

What she eats now (1500 calories)



BREAKFAST: Porridge

LUNCH: Homemade soup

DINNER: Chicken, rice and vegetables

SNACKS: Apples
articles.teaser: HOLLY Francis shed dramatic 11st after tragic miscarriage was linked to her obesity
articles.headline: 'Binges cost £25k and baby's life'
articles.subdeck: Holly Francis ... slim and healthy after tragic miscarriage prompted dramatic weight loss

image.caption: A Mother's Day wish ... Louise Redknapp with her son

articles.articlebody:
LOUISE Redknapp is no stranger to what it takes to be a mum, with two young sons to look after as well as juggling a busy schedule.

And the TV presenter has been looking forward to spending some quality time with her own mother as well as her children this Mother's Day.

However the 37-year-old is also keen to raise awareness of those families who won't enjoy such a relaxing time on Sunday.

The star has previously spent time meeting both mums and children in East Africa where she was shocked at what she saw.

Here Louise speaks about her experiences, the work being done by humanitarian aid charity UNICEF and how you can help.

"I cherish my relationship with my mum, she's my rock in so many aspects of my life. I treat her as often as I can and when Mother's Day comes around I try and do something a little extra special.

"This coming Mother's Day I know that my two boys will wake me up with breakfast in bed, it's usually burnt toast and a luke warm cup of tea, and it will be the best breakfast I'll have all year!

"I know we'll have a lovely family day but for many mothers around the world they won't be comforted by those certainties, they have no idea how their day will begin or how it will end.

"I'll be thinking of these mums this Mothers Day who'll be fighting to save their child's life, desperately trying to find enough food so that their child can survive Mother's Day, and then the next day and every day after that.

"I'm sure you've seen in the news, as I have, that more than a million children across both East and West Africa are at risk of dying over the coming months if they do not receive more help soon.

"UNICEF, the world's leading children's organisation, is already there with local partners to try and help children and their families before its too late, but they urgently need more funds to be able to do this.

"As a mum, all you want to do is protect and provide for your family, I can't begin to feel how desperate, frustrated and anxious these mums must be all the time without any food to feed their children.

"I have travelled to East Africa and I found the sight of malnourished children heartbreaking. I talked to some of these kids and was shocked to hear how little they ate on a daily basis.

"I find it almost impossible to imagine that with a supermarket on every corner and all the food I could want, that around the world every hour, 300 children are still dying from hunger.

"Just think, by the time you've read this paper, had a cup of tea and phoned your mum, another 300 children will have died, just because they don't have enough to eat.

"This Mother's Day, it's not about feeling guilty for what you've got, or feeling like you can't be spoilt. Of course you can. It's just about taking a moment to remember these mums and their children who won't be celebrating this year, and do your bit to help them.

"I'm doing my bit by supporting UNICEF's Mother's Day campaign and you can too.

"UNICEF is calling on everyone to buy a Nutritional Inspired Gift, which are life saving food supplies delivered directly to the mums and the children that need it most, like those in West Africa.

"My favourite is a special high protein paste  Plumpy Nut - which can take a child from the brink of death to healthy in a matter of weeks. You can help save a life for just £12, that's pretty amazing and that's exactly what I'll be buying my mum this Mother's Day.

This Mother's Day help a mum save their child's life and buy a nutritional UNICEF Inspired gift from www.unicef.org.uk/inspired. "
articles.teaser: LOUISE Redknapp talks about her love for her mother and UNICEF
articles.headline: Louise's Mother's Day message
articles.subdeck: A Mother's Day wish ... Louise Redknapp with her son

image.caption: Risky business ... new warning highlights danger of unqualified beauty therapists

article.caption: I was terrified my PIP implants were a ticking timebomb. I just wanted them out
I spent £10,000 to look like one of my Barbies

articles.articlebody:
THOUSANDS of women are putting themselves at risk by inviting rogue beauty therapists into their homes.

Some agencies, such as online beauty therapist directory mobilebeauty.uk.com, allow anyone to register and advertise for work with NO checks.

Lauren Shalson, co-founder and director of reputable company Spa By Car, says: "Many online beauty agencies offer work or let therapists register based simply on a phone call. How can you safely send someone into a client's home without at least meeting them in person?

"After a thorough interview process, to be accepted on to our books our therapists need a minimum of NVQ level 2 and 3 and arrive in branded clothing, a branded car and bring proof of certificates to the appointment.

"We, as clients, need to be fully aware we could be letting anyone into our home and of the danger we could be placing ourselves in, especially if opting for a specialist treatment like intimate waxing. The mobile beauty sector is enjoying a surge because clients want therapies in the safety of their own home.

"Yet unscrupulous operators are sending unvetted, unqualified and uninsured therapists to clients' homes  exposing them to unimaginable risks. If you are using a mobile beauty therapist I would ask for references. If you are to use one at all I would use one that has been recommended to you and who has proved they can do a good job.

"I would ask who their insurance provider is and for proof of training  especially if you are going for eyelash extensions, where sharp tweezers are used which could cause a lot of damage in the hands of the wrong person. Be warned!"
articles.teaser: THOUSANDS of women are putting themselves at risk by inviting rogue beauty therapists into their homes
articles.headline: Truth about rogue beauticians...
articles.subdeck: Risky business ... new warning highlights danger of unqualified beauty therapists

image.caption: Baby ambition ... June dressed as boxer, doctor, matador, surfer and bishop

articles.articlebody:
A CREATIVE dad has given his three-month-old daughter insight into life as a grown-up through a series of funny costume photos.

Father-of-three Eric Maloberti dressed his little girl in outfits showcasing different career choices, for a project entitled Un Jour, Mon Enfant Tu Seras  which translates as One Day, My Child You Will Be.

The amusing snaps show June wearing everything from a mini bishop outfit to a boxer's kit and gloves  with a fake black eye to match.

The photographer  known as Malo  and his wife designed the costumes to show what life can hold when babies grow up.

And baby June was his inspiration, giving him the idea of photographically capturing the fears every parent has for what their child will become.

Malo, 39, said: "The idea behind the project is that we do not know what our children will become.

"As parents we do hope for our children to become symbols and icons, like an athlete, a Miss Something pageant queen or a rock star.

"I found the idea amusing and so began my project."

The couple, who live in Paris, said they produced the pictures "very quickly" to ensure June would not get tired.

Malo explained his reasons behind the project  to tell parents they should want their children to do whatever makes them happy.

He said: "I want people to look at these pictures and be touched and think of their children.

"The innocence of babies is what resonates with the public and on a serious note I would want other mums and dads to look at their kids and think what would make them happiest when they grow up."

He added: "If your child wants to be a priest then tell them they can be and if your child wants to be a bishop tell them that is good too."
articles.teaser: FUNNY pictures show baby dressed in series of outfits showcasing what she may grow up to be
articles.headline: When I grow up I want to be a boxer
articles.subdeck: Baby ambition ... June dressed as boxer, doctor, matador, surfer and bishop

image.caption: Gift ... Swati and Kanchan

article.caption: My 8-year takeaway binge cost £25k...and my unborn baby's life
Thanks a bunch mum, we bloomin' love you
Bloomin' shame

articles.articlebody:
A LOVING daughter gave her sick mum the ultimate Mother's Day gift  the kidney that saved her life.

Now mum-of-three Kanchan Bhagat and Swati are planning an extra special day tomorrow  to celebrate a year since their op.

Kanchan, 58, had suffered from kidney disease for 12 years when her condition suddenly worsened in 2010.

Doctors said she could die unless a donor was found quickly  and Swati, 30, stepped forward. The pair underwent a two-hour op and were both released from hospital on Mother's Day last year.

Swati, a healthcare professional, said: "Finding out it had been a success on Mothering Sunday was the best gift I could have given  even if I wasn't able to get her a card.

"When I first suggested donating a kidney, she was adamant I wasn't to risk my health for hers  but I wouldn't take no for an answer. Mum has always been there for me and I was able to show her how grateful I am."

Kanchan, who has returned to work at Sainsbury's, added: "Last Mother's Day was emotional. There was lots of joking because Swati's sister Heeta got me flowers but Swati hadn't bought anything. I said, 'It's OK  you have just given me a kidney'."

Kanchan, from Harrow, North West London, plans to spend this Sunday with her husband Suresh, 59, their son Piyush, 35, Swati and Heeta, 29.

a.parker@the-sun.co.uk
articles.teaser: A LOVING daughter gave her sick mum the ultimate Mother's Day gift  the kidney that saved her life
articles.headline: I gave mum my kidney for Mother's Day
articles.subdeck: Gift ... Swati and Kanchan

image.caption: Curvy ... Steps star Claire Richards

article.caption: My 8-year takeaway binge cost £25k...and my unborn baby's life
They remember all of the Steps
Re-live Sun webchat with reunited Steps
Britney Spears 'split up Steps'
Claire Richards: I starved myself to stay in showbiz
Steps star Claire up to 15 stone

articles.articlebody:
STEPS star Claire Richards has vowed to stop her yo-yo dieting  and reckons at size 16 she has never been happier.

In an interview with The Sun she hit back at her latest critics, who have claimed she is too fat for the dance routines in the band's comeback shows.

Claire, 34, revealed that her famous weight problems started back in the Nineties, when she was a svelte size 10 and trying out for the band.

She said: "At the audition I was told to lose weight if I wanted to be in Steps, so I did. That set me on the road of starvation for a few years."

Now the singer, whose 22-date comeback tour with Steps starts on April 2, refuses to bow to that sort of pressure.

She said: "I have spent so many years starving myself to be skinny. You can damage yourself by doing that  and I probably have in some ways.

"I think it's really sad that there is so much emphasis on a woman's size, certainly in the music industry.

"It's not really fair, and it doesn't make your average woman feel that great about herself. It makes you feel low.

"You are being told by magazines that you shouldn't look like that, you should be skinny  and that's just not the way it is.

"Being a size 16 doesn't mean you don't look good.

"You are brainwashed into thinking you can't wear nice clothes because you are a little bigger and you have to wear baggy stuff to hide whatever's going on underneath  and it's rubbish.

"I'm a size 14 to 16 and I have a waist, I have boobs and I have a bum. I can accentuate those assets and still wear a nice dress and feel good about myself.

"It is important to remember that a size 16 is the average size of a woman in the UK. It is odd how these women are made to feel like they are not the norm but they are."

At the height of her fame with Steps Claire starved herself to a size eight before becoming a size 20 when the band split in 2001. Her weight has fluctuated ever since.

She said of the latest criticism: "The stories circulating about me struggling with dance moves are complete rubbish.

"I don't know where that has come from. Maybe someone has thought, 'Oh, she's bigger than the others so she must be struggling'. It's not an issue. It is just one of those things. People have just got to be nasty sometimes.

"I am putting in as much work and effort as everybody else.

"It is tough  it's a two-hour show, dancing for pretty much the whole thing. Just because I am a bigger size, I am no less fit than anybody else. It's cr*p.

"You can run every day and be fit and then be put in the situation that we are all in and you are using muscles you didn't even know you had.

"It's not as simple as someone being fit and someone not being fit  or someone being a size 16 and someone being a size 8.

"It's all going well. I don't know if it's because I'm a bit older now but I seem to be much more focused and picking up choreography better than I ever did.

"I'm not a trained dancer so that was always something I struggled with. Now we are just making sure it all looks perfect. I am in the middle of rehearsals at the moment, so it is a bit manic but really good."

Claire admits the interest in her size is something she has got used to.

She said: "The obsession with my size gets on my nerves a lot less now than it used to. I am happy with the way I am."

Claire lives in Middlesex with her hubby Reece, 43, an electrician and their children, Charlie, four, and two-year-old Daisy.

She added: "My husband loves me, my kids love me and nobody I am working with thinks it's an issue. If I look out into that audience when I'm up on stage with Steps, at least there will be women out there just like me who will feel a bit better about themselves because I am not a size 8.

"I am not trying to make a stand about my figure  but I've been a size 8 and I was miserable. I probably could have gone down to that size again  but what's the point if you are not going to be that for ever?

"I don't want to be yo-yoing any more  and if that means I'll just be a bit bigger, that's just the way it's got to be.

"It's not like I am starting out now. Steps wouldn't be the same if I wasn't in it, so they can't say to me now, 'You have to lose weight otherwise you can't be in the group'.

"There is no way anyone could tell me I'm too big or I have to lose weight now  because they can't do the tour without me.

"As a group, we always said if one of us didn't want to do it, then it wouldn't happen. They are certainly not going to kick me out for being a size 16."

Claire is also hosting Lorraine's Cake Club, a search on Sun columnist Lorraine Kelly's ITV show to find Britain's best cake.

And the singer reckons most online comments and tweets about her are supportive.

She said: "I would say that 95 per cent of people are saying, 'I think she looks great'.

"From doing the TV show Slave To Food last year about the kind of trouble I have had to deal with about my weight, I was surprised by the response I got.

"I had people saying, 'Thank you, you are so brave for doing that show. I can now look at a person on telly and say that she is just like me'.

"Many women have said to me, 'Hearing you talk about this stuff is like looking in the mirror.'

"There aren't many of us out there who will be honest and say, 'I struggle with my weight'.

"I don't really want to struggle any more, so this is me  and if you don't like it, tough."

n.watkins@the-sun.co.uk



Claire's changing body



1999  size 8, 8st 7Ib



2005  size 16, 13st



2008  size 18, 15st



2008  size 10, 10st 7Ib



2009  size 18, 15st



2011  size 14-16, 12st

articles.articlebody:
WHEN Michael Brown lost his wife Sheila to cancer six years ago he was understandably devastated.

But when his daughter Clare Wood was murdered by a man she met on Facebook three years later, his only comfort was the fact that Sheila had been spared the nightmare he now had to endure.

Michael, 68, says: "Perhaps losing Sheila when she was 49 was meant to be  it almost feels like a blessing now.

"The only thing worse than having to live with what happened to Clare would have been to see the unbearable pain it would have caused her mother.

"At least she has been spared this terrible heartache."

Clare was 36 when she was strangled and set on fire by her ex-boyfriend, George Appleton, at her home in Salford, Greater Manchester in February 2009.

Appleton then went on the run before hanging himself.

Clare, a mother of one, had been unaware of his history of violence against women, including repeated harassment, threats and the kidnapping at knifepoint of one of his exes.

At the inquest into her death, Coroner Jennifer Leeming said women in abusive relationships should have the right to know about the violent past of the men they were with.

Now, under a pilot scheme  dubbed Clare's Law  to be trialled from this summer, both women and men in four regions of the UK are to have the right to ask police if a new partner has a history of violence. It will soon be rolled out nationally.

Michael, from Batley, West Yorkshire, says: "If this had been in place in time for Clare then I'm certain she would still be alive today.

"She would have realised the danger she was in and come home to her dad, where I would have been able to protect her."

When Clare first introduced Appleton to her father, he was instantly concerned. He says: "As soon as he walked through the door I didn't like him. Alarms bells started ringing  somehow I knew he was bad."

But gradually Michael, a retired policeman, accepted the relationship.

He says: "As her dad my role wasn't to interfere. It was always to be waiting in the background to pick up the pieces if things went wrong."

Clare, who was living in Salford, ended the relationship in October 2008, much to Michael's relief. He recalls: "I asked why but she never gave me a proper answer. Then at Christmas she said she'd had to report him to the police for being a pest."

Clare didn't tell her dad about the sexual assaults and violence that Appleton had inflicted on her during their relationship. Michael adds: "She never got into any trouble or bother, not even as a child. When she was a kid I always told her that the first time she brought the police to the door she would be grounded.

"She never did  at least not until the day they came to tell me she was dead. It was unthinkable something so gruesome could have happened to my own child."

Six days later Appleton was found hanged and Michael adds: "There was an element of relief that it was finished now."

In the months that followed Michael discovered what a monster Clare had been dating.

He says: "I found out that four crime numbers had been assigned to my daughter regarding this man  including physical abuse and attempted rape.

"It came out that he'd been in prison for harassment and holding an ex at knifepoint.

"I couldn't believe this information hadn't been passed on to Clare when she first reported him. At that point there were three non-harassment orders in situ to different girls.

"If Clare had been made aware of this she would have known he was capable of anything. The police let her down."

Now Michael is determined that Clare's Law will be easily accessible to girls like Clare.

He says: "This is so women can make informed decisions about their own safety.

"If Clare's death can stop even a handful more girls being killed then I'll have some comfort. I will have achieved something good out of something truly terrible."

Sex Lessons: Different sex drives

Research varies but a recent study has found as many as 50 per cent of couples experience mismatched sex drives. So if he or she is always pestering you for sex - and you just don't have the interest - you've got a lot of company.

It's not really surprising - after all when you got together he preferred pizza and she preferred Chinese. He loved an action holiday and she loved lying on the beach. So why wouldn't your sex drives be different too?

But there's double-trouble when this happens. The partner who has a higher drive feels neglected. And the partner who has a lower drive feels pestered or inadequate.

I can only hope this marriage gives her the stability she needs because she'll need to provide her baby with stability. It doesn't happen in reverse - babies aren't there to make you feel better about yourself or to give your life meaning.

Sex Lessons: Rev-up your sex life for 2012

articles.articlebody:
CUT-price Kate is at it again  but this time the High Street style queen has been hitting the thrift shops.

Last week it was revealed the Duchess sent aides to a second-hand dress agency just a few miles from her Berkshire family home to find her outfits.

Her nearly new purchases from The Stock Exchange, in Sunninghill, include the grey Jesire coat dress she wore to a National Portrait Gallery event last month.

Described as a "premier venue for the fashion-conscious bargain hunter", the shop sells unwanted designer gear for clients and takes a 50 per cent cut of the sale price.

We sent Sun stylist Nana Acheampong to the shop to put together a wardrobe that was fit for a princess.

She found top High Streets labels including Kate's favourites LK Bennett and Karen Millen, plus fashion house labels including Chloe.

Nana, 25, said: "Staff revealed the store takes donations from a host of local TV presenters. They get a cut of any sales but anything not sold after five weeks goes to charity.

"They haven't seen the Duchess in the store but they were really excited when they saw Kate on TV wearing the Jesire dress.

"It looks like the Duchess has a secret shopper and The Stock Exchange are keen for whoever it is to continue shopping there."

Nana managed to put together four outfits for less than £180.

Here, Kate lookalike Chelsea Collins, 22, from Poole, Dorset, models our princess perfect looks.

articles.articlebody:
CORRIE'S Jimmi Harkishin has struck up a bizarre friendship with a hardcore porn actress.

The Street favourite  who has played shopkeeper Dev Alahan for 13 years  took porn star Kat Lee along to a showbiz premiere as his date.

The pair attended the first night of musical Chicago at Manchester's Palace Theatre with other TV celebs.

Kat, 25, has starred in a series of no-holds-barred adult films  with titles including Sex Dolls and Sugar Daddy. At the start of the night, brunette Kat arrived at the theatre alone, followed around 30 seconds later by Jimmi, 52.

But once inside the foyer, they were spotted cuddling up as they headed to the bar. The pair then sat together as they watched the show.

Afterwards, they were spotted in Jimmi's car sharing a bag of chips.

An onlooker in the theatre said: "A few people know who this girl is and they were shocked to see her there with Jimmi. But he didn't seem to care. He had his arm around her and was introducing her to people in there. He tried to cover things up by making her walk separately from him. But then they sat in a car eating chips."

Later the pair were spotted heading to Kat's city centre flat and Jimmi didn't leave until well after midnight.

Yesterday all Kat would say was: "I was at the show with him but I don't want to talk about it."

In 2008, Jimmi claimed his crazy days were behind him.

He said: "I can't drink. I can't stay up too late. But I actually like getting older."

At the height of his troubles, in 2004, Jimmi was suspended from his £100,000-a- year role in Corrie after being caught taking cocaine with a girlfriend.

Jimmi's love life has been just as colourful as his character Dev's. He was caught several times cheating on his former long-term partner and mum of his two children Susan Beaton.

A source said: "Jimmi keeps his love life very close to his chest.

"But now it looks like he and Kat are getting close. He has always had a colourful love life."

articles.articlebody:
FORMER Emmerdale lesbian Jenna-Louise Coleman has today been named as Dr Who's new assistant  as we first revealed last night.

The pretty 25-year-old impressed bosses with her screen test and chemistry with star Matt Smith.

This morning show boss Steven Moffat said: "We saw a lot of brilliant actresses. But Jenna was the only person going faster than Matt - he had to keep up!

"It always seems impossible when you start casting these parts, but when we saw Matt and Jenna together, we knew we had our girl. She's funny and clever and exactly mad enough to step on board the TARDIS.

"It's not often the Doctor meets someone who can talk even faster than he does, but it's about to happen."

And teased: "Jenna is going to lead him his merriest dance yet."

Jenna-Louise will take over when Karen Gillan, who plays Amy Pond, leaves the hit BBC sci-fi drama this year.

The actress, who also stars in ITV1's new big budget Titanic drama this Sunday, is best known as Emmerdale's Jasmine Thomas.

She said: "I'm beyond excited, I can't wait to get cracking; working alongside Matt I know is going to be enormous fun and a huge adventure."

She will first be seen on screens at Christmas.

Moffat also confirmed that Doctor Who will air six episodes in 2012 and a further eight in 2013 for the show's 50th anniversary.
articles.teaser: ACTRESS is fave for role after impressing chiefs with screen test & chemistry with Smith
articles.headline: 'Dale Jen new pal for Dr Who
articles.subdeck: Who's that girl ... Jenna-Louise Coleman

image.caption: New role ... Eddie Izzard will star in Mockingbird Lane

articles.articlebody:
EDDIE Izzard has landed a monster new role  as womanising vampire Grandpa Munster!

The British comedianturned-actor will star in new US comedy drama Mockingbird Lane, which is a revamped and updated version of classic 1960s family-friendly comedy The Munsters.

Eddie, 50, will play the role made famous by Al Lewis.

Head of the freaky family, Grandpa Munster  aka Sam Dracula  was a 300-year-old lady-loving vampire, who could change himself into other creatures including a bat and a wolf.

He was dad to Lily Munster and father-in-law to Herman, who lived together with their monster son Eddie and Lily's sister Marilyn at 1313 Mockingbird Lane.

Eddie  who also starred in US drama The Riches and films including Oceans 12 and 13  is believed to have signed up to play the role and also to produce the new series for NBC.

Mockingbird Lane is being written by Bryan Fuller (who created Pushing Daisies) and directed by Bryan Singer of X-Men fame.
articles.teaser: COMEDIAN Izzard will play Grandpa Munster in revamp of the freaky family comedy show
articles.headline: Eddie sinks his teeth into comedy vampire role

CORRIE favourite Jimmi Harkishin's porn star pal Kat Lee appeared in an episode of Jeremy Kyle with her twin sister Kit and their gran, it has emerged.

The sisters' distraught grandmother Pat appeared in a programme with the theme "Is my granddaughter forcing her twin into porn and prostitution?".

The footage, which aired around three years ago, showed Kat, 25, real name Zayna Ellemore, explaining that she has been in multiple X-rated videos with her sibling.

And although she was a willing participant, Kit, real name Noor Ellemore, accused Kat of being the ringleader in their career in blue movies and escorting.

She also said her sister snubbed her away from their workplace.

Talk show ringmaster Jeremy asked three audience members to watch some of their raunchy movies and the ladies told of their disgust after viewing them.

Earlier this week 52-year-old Jimmi  who has played shopkeeper Dev Alahan for 13 years  took Kat along to a showbiz premiere as his date.

The pair attended the first night of musical Chicago at Manchester's Palace Theatre with other TV celebs.

Later the pair were spotted heading to Kat's city centre flat and Jimmi didn't leave until well after midnight.

Yesterday all Kat would say was: "I was at the show with him but I don't want to talk about it."

articles.articlebody:
CHEEKY Celia Sawyer has revealed the secret behind becoming an antiques show guru  ASK.

The straight-talking blonde saw a Channel 4 advert asking viewers to send in snaps of their vintage treasures that could appear on Four Rooms.

But instead of putting forward an intriguing object, the feisty interior designer advertised herself as curious collectable  by emailing her own pic to producers.

Celia  who admits she would use her feminine charms to clinch a deal  revealed: "I sent a picture of myself and wrote underneath how about me as a dealer? I did it off the cuff and never expected a reply."

The glam 45-year-old blonde  who appears alongside Andrew Lamberty, Jeff Salmon and Gordon Watson on the show, which sees contestants try to flog their valuables to four competing dealers  told how her favourite items in the second series include Muhammad Ali's boxing gloves.

Astonishingly Hitler's toilet seat, a Victorian sex aid and the Duchess of Cambridge's car also feature on the show.

And other artefacts include a portion of Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip's wedding cake, Richard Burton's fur coat, the chair on which JK Rowling wrote Harry Potter and artwork by Marlon Brando.

Four Rooms is on tonight at 8pm.

articles.articlebody:
AMANDA Holden has revealed she will be hosting Andrew Lloyd Webber's new ITV1 show Jesus Christ Superstar.

Lloyd Webber is looking for a big talent to lead a revival of his '70s rock opera.

The winner of the reality show will star in a special arena tour that will open at London's O2 and play at Britain's biggest venue.

And today Amanda, 41, has told how she will present the search for a super voice.

Amanda  who had a near-death experience when she gave birth to daughter Hollie Rose  joked: "As I have a West End background, and I nearly met Jesus the other week, I'm the best qualified."

Speaking about the new job, she also told This Morning's Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield: "We haven't signed on the dotted line yet, but I am. I'm not sure if I'm supposed to talk about it!"

Revealing more about the talent search, Amanda  who played Fiona in the musical version of Shrek  added: "They've gone all over the country and Andrew said they've even had some girls auditioning to play Jesus as well.

"I'm not sure they've sorted out the judging panel yet but it's going to be a huge arena tour and it'll go worldwide."

Jesus Christ Superstar will air on ITV1 later this year after Lloyd Webber was lured away from the BBC.

His musical reality shows How Do You Solve A Problem Like Maria?, I'd Do Anything, Any Dream Will Do and Over The Rainbow had all been screened on the Beeb.

GOT To Dance judge Kimberly Wyatt looks a far cry from her usual self in this plane Twitter pic.

The beauty posted the photo online on Monday with the message: "Private room security pat down. Bags searched as I'm boarding the plane. Dubai better be amazing!!!"

The star, 30, had banished her usual heavy make-up for a fresh-faced look as she took off on her holidays.

And earlier today the excited singer told fans: "Getting ready to be a tourist!! :)"

Last month, Kimberly confessed she fancies the pants off TV presenter Davina McCall.

The ex-Pussycat Doll  who has been dating US actor Kevin Schmidt since early 2009  admitted she developed the girl crush while the pair filmed Got To Dance together.

Kimberly said: "I think Davina is one of the most amazing, most incredible women I have ever met in my entire life.

"I am quite star-struck by her. Honestly, I have developed a girl crush."

articles.articlebody:
KEITH Lemon looked like he was ready to knock out a photographer, after failing to pick up a Royal Television Society Award at last night's bash.

But the Celebrity Juice funnyman was only joking with the snapper, as he left the swanky Grosvenor House Hotel on London's Park Lane.

While Keith might not have been happy to have left empty-handed, the cast of Coronation Street were over the moon, as the ITV1 show picked up the best soap award.

Street sirens including Brooke Vincent (Sophie Webster), Jane Danson (Leanne Barlow) and Samia Ghadie (Maria Connor) looked stunning after glamming up for the annual bash.

Andrew Lancel looked on fine form, no doubt relieved that the speculation about 'who killed Frank Foster' was finally over, and he laughed with Emmerdale's Danny Miller (Aaron Livesey) who has also just left soapland.

Other stars at the ceremony included Caroline Flack, who flashed her bronzed pins in a tiny playsuit, plus Derren Brown, Russell Tovey and Dominic West.

Some of the RTS Award winners:

articles.articlebody:
SINGER Jason Donovan has ended one of pop's great mysteries  by admitting he HAS had a hair transplant.

The former chart star owned up to having the same surgery as footballer Wayne Rooney.

His confession came as he was tipped to join ex-girlfriend Kylie Minogue at a concert to celebrate the 1980s. Strictly star Jason, 43, was forced to confess his surgery after blurting it out in front of a packed audience during filming for Piers Morgan's Life Stories on Saturday night.

He told The Sun: "I am really happy with the results. It's something I did just for myself and haven't felt the need to publicise it."

Jason has always refused to divulge his hair transplant treatment despite it looking thicker on Strictly. A pal said last night: "This is not just Jason being vain. He is a guy who works in showbusiness and he feels more comfortable with hair.

"Piers was being cheeky about his hair apparently thickening and he let slip that he'd 'done a Rooney'."

Jason is set to join Kylie, 43, on stage to sing their 1989 No1 Especially For You at a concert in London's Hyde Park on July 11.

c.robertson@the-sun.co.uk

image.caption: Anger ... Simon Cowell, left, wants David Walliams, right, to avoid Tom Jones' The Voice

article.caption: Simon Cowell: Britain's Got Talent is cooler
Tom Jones's Voice is fine, but he's hard of Jiear-ing
Simon Cowell: 'BGT is so cool'
A Hol' lot of love
Will.i.am blasts Beeb backstage with bass
X Factor is going back to basics

articles.articlebody:
THE rivalry between The Voice and Britain's Got Talent stepped up a gear last night after Simon Cowell BANNED David Walliams from going to see the new BBC show.

Little Britain star David wanted to attend one of the live shows the Beeb's new £22million singing contest will stage later in the run.

He was keen to take his mum Kathleen, 68, to see Welsh crooner Tom Jones, who is on the show's judging panel.

As frequent visitors to Strictly Come Dancing, David and his mum were hoping to get tickets.

But after Simon found out, BGT judge David decided against the move for fear of antagonising his new boss and being branded a TRAITOR.

An insider told TV Biz: "Simon is gunning for The Voice.

"He wants to destroy it and is really unhappy that it's going up against BGT.

"He doesn't want anyone associated with his show being linked with The Voice  and that includes being seen sitting in the audience.

"If David turned up, the BBC would use loads of shots of him in the audience and viewers would think he preferred The Voice.

"It's a battlefield mentality  you're either with Simon or against him. There are no half measures."

David, pictured above with Simon and Tom, often takes his devoted mum to showbiz events and he even roped her in to help with one of his decisions on BGT.

At the Hammersmith Apollo auditions he couldn't make his mind up about a young classical singer.

He said: "This sounds like the kind of thing I'd buy my mother for Mother's Day. Then, turning round, he called out to his mum, saying: "My mum's in the audience  Mum, would you be happy with that?"

TV Biz revealed how BGT bosses brought forward the start date for this year's series in a bid to strangle The Voice at birth.

The sixth season of the ITV1 talent trawl was due to start on March 31.

But once executives discovered its rival was launching a week earlier, they moved the launch date forward.



Alesha on the Loose

BRITAIN'S Got Talent bosses had Alesha Dixon parachuted in as a guest on ITV's Loose Women after hearing The Voice star Danny O'Donoghue was due to appear.

Judge Alesha was called in to join the girls on Friday amid fears Danny would grab too much publicity for the new BBC rival.

A source said: "It really is war now. Where The Voice goes, BGT is lurking in the shadows. It would be funny if it wasn't so ridiculous."

STRICTLY'S Craig Revel Horwood has criticised Alesha for not telling the other judges she was quitting the show. Craig said: "It was a shock because we found out through the Press. I was a bit disappointed. I wish she had texted or called."

But he still wishes the singer well in her debut on Britain's Got Talent, on Saturday. He said: "Good luck to her. I hope it works out."
articles.teaser: BGT judge keen to see Tom Jones in action for BBC but backs down to avoid Si's fury
articles.headline: Judge and fury
articles.subdeck: Anger ... Simon Cowell, left, wants David Walliams, right, to avoid Tom Jones' The Voice

articles.articlebody:
CHERYL COLE is set to launch her new single on The Voice in a move guaranteed to infuriate former boss Simon Cowell.

Her performance on BBC1's rival to Cowell's Britain's Got Talent was organised by her close pal Will.i.am, who is a judge on the new series.

It will be timed to coincide with the launch of her new album next month.

But sources insist that rumours the former X Factor judge will be a mentor on the BBC1 show are wrong.

A source from The Voice said of the singer's deal yesterday: "It's great news as we've made no secret of the fact we love Cheryl. But obviously Simon will be annoyed as he hates The Voice."

Simon and Cheryl famously fell out after he dumped her from the US X Factor's judging panel last year after just three weeks in the job.

But the pair have recently made up.

article.caption: Engelbert's Eurovision song is revealed
Is this the worst Eurovision song ever?
Engelbert: I'll win Eurovision Song Contest
Lulu: I didn't do That with Jason Orange
Fans get the Hump at UK Euro entry

articles.articlebody:
EUROVISION star Engelbert Humperdinck says he still gets knickers thrown at him during performances  despite being 75 years old.

The crooner, a surprise choice to represent the UK at the annual song contest in May, insists he remains a sex symbol to many women.

He said: "I still occasionally get knickers thrown at me, yes.

"I think it is the people that want to be noticed."

He joked: "What I should do is throw mine at them."

The old smoothie, who says he feels more like he is in his fifties than his eighth decade  claims he has never had cosmetic surgery, but admits he dyes his locks.

He said: "I certainly hope I don't act or look my age and I certainly haven't been into any Beverly Hills surgeries. I've got my mother and father's genes.

"When I was 25 I had grey hair. I said to myself, 'If I am going to be in showbusiness I can't go out there with grey hair as a young man.'

"So I started dying my hair really jet black and I created the image with the sideburns. I've been dyeing my hair ever since."

"Lately it has got a little lighter. I don't want to be black-haired at the age of 75."

Despite his fame the Brit  who lives in Los Angeles for part of the year  insisted he is down to earth and loves nothing more than a pint of bitter when he is back in the UK.

He said: "I love the beer. When I come home I must get it out of my system by having a pint of bitter and bag of crisps.

"I say to my driver, 'Pull over', and I stop at a pub."

Bizarrely, Engelbert plans to take a dartboard to the May 26 song contest in Azerbaijan.

The star said: "I love darts. I take a board wherever I work around the world."

His bid for Eurovision glory suffered a blow yesterday when it was revealed the UK's entrant will sing FIRST, often one of the worst slots as viewers may have forgotten the song by voting time.

Bookies lengthened his odds to win from 14-1 to 16-1, making him the eighth favourite.

He admitted: "It is tough to come out of the box first but that's what I have to accept.

"If your first impression is a good one hopefully this will carry through the competition."

Engelbert's Eurovision song  called Love Will Set You Free and likened by some to the Big Fat Gypsy Weddings theme tune  was released on Monday. He said: "My aim is to keep it classy. I hope I can live up to the standards my country is looking for."

Engelbert has checked out some of the opposition, including Ireland's Jedward and said: "They are talented kids and they have a great sense of humour."

Looking forward to after the contest The Hump, as he is known, said: "It would be a delight to share my experience with some of the young ones. I'd love to duet with Adele as she is the hottest mustard in the park."

Despite his age, Engelbert said he is in good health, adding: "I love sport. I play tennis and golf and waterski whenever I go away for a small vacation. That is what has kept me youthful."

He also refused to criticise his ex-manager Gordon Mills, who died in 1986 but is alleged to have stolen millions from the singer during his heyday.

He said: "He started my career, he was a great man. Whatever the case may be, whatever he did I knew nothing about it."
articles.byline: By LEIGH HOLMWOOD, Deputy TV Editor
articles.teaser: THE Eurovision crooner Humperdinck says he still drives girls wild despite age
articles.headline: Engelbert: I'm still sex symbol
articles.subdeck: Surprise choice ... Engelbert Humperdinck

articles.articlebody:
STRICTLY stars Harry Judd and Chelsee Healey have added scuba gear to their sequins and spray tans to waltz UNDERWATER for Sport Relief.

Harry admitted: "When I first heard about Strictly Underwater, I thought, 'How is that going to work?'. I didn't quite understand what they meant and I didn't think it would work  but it does."

Meanwhile Waterloo Road actress Chelsee, runner-up to McFly drummer Harry in December's Strictly final, said: "I wouldn't say I'm a strong swimmer and I'm not keen on water.

"I like a bath in it but that's about as far as it goes."

BBC1 will screen the scenes as part of Sport Relief night on Friday from 7pm.

article.caption: West actor for Dominic?

articles.articlebody:
COMEDIAN Dara O'Briain will take over from Graham Norton to present this year's Baftas.

Graham  who won a gong for his BBC1 chatshow at last year's awards  has been forced to step aside because he will be presenting the Eurovision Song Contest, which falls on the same weekend.

The Baftas, which honour the best TV seen in Britain over the past year, will be held on May 27 at London's Royal Festival Hall and broadcast on BBC1.

Mock The Week host Dara said: "I'm delighted and honoured to be taking the reins at this year's British Academy Television Awards, in the prestigious role as the person who introduces the people who read out the winners of the awards. And if Adele wins anything, I promise I'll leave her well alone, no matter what time it is."

BBC's controller of entertainment commissioning Mark Linsey added: "We know Dara will do a magnificent job in Graham's absence."

Jimmy Carr's Big Fat virgins

articles.articlebody:
PEEP Show star David Mitchell is to marry girlfriend Victoria Coren.

The funnyman, 37, who also stars in 10 O'Clock Live, has been dating Only Connect host Victoria, 38, for "some time", having confirmed that he was seeing someone in late 2010.

The couple made their happy announcement earlier today via an entry in the Births, Marriages and Deaths column of today's Times newspaper.

It read: "MR D.J.S. MITCHELL AND MISS V.E. COREN. The engagement is announced between David, son of Mr and Mrs Ian Mitchell, of Oxford, and Victoria, daughter of Dr Anne Coren and the late Mr Alan Coren, of London."

Victoria, who is a British writer, presenter and champion poker player, wrote on Twitter: "Thank you for your nice tweets this morning. I'm very happy."

And David added: "Having received so many lovely messages today, I'm finally coming round to the idea of the internet. Thank you all. I'm incredibly happy."

THIS is the first picture of Corrie's Kym Marsh as Street legend Elsie Tanner in the new stage musical based on the soap.

Kym  Michelle Connor on TV  will play the saucepot during the 1960s.

Pat Phoenix starred as Elsie from 1960 to 1984, and Kym said: "She's left some rather big stiletto shoes to fill."

Street Of Dreams will begin touring the country in May. Corrie veterans Bill Roache, Julie Goodyear and Kevin Kennedy also appear.

articles.articlebody:
JANUARY JONES is dressed fur success in a winter jacket days before the return of Mad Men.

The gorgeous star was a man-magnet in her faux fur, leather jeans and shades out in New York on Monday.

Not that she needs any sexy gear.

Jon Hamm  Donald Draper in the hit US drama, which returns on Sky Atlantic at 9pm on Tuesday  reckons his female co-stars are so hot they would look good in bin liners.

Appearing on ITV1's Lorraine yesterday, Jon said: "You could put Christina (Hendricks) and January in garbage bags and they'd look sexy. I think the fact they look this sexy on screen has a lot to do with what our costume designer puts them in. It's a good look."
